awd_titl_txt: NRT-INFEWS: STEM Training for Actionable Research and Global Impact
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Research Traineeship (NRT) award to the University of California at Berkeley will address challenges at the nexus of food, energy, and water systems (FEWS) through the lens of alleviating poverty and promoting equity. Poor communities often face extreme challenges accessing nutritious food, clean and reliable energy, and safe water, which will be amplified with additional climate variability, population growth, stress on infrastructures, and pollution in the future. Through collaborative and immersive interdisciplinary training, graduate students will develop novel and lasting interdisciplinary approaches and technologies for solving FEWS challenges and reducing poverty with positive global impact. The program will engage over 400 students with up to 80 trainees, including 32 funded trainees, from engineering, social sciences, environmental sciences, business, and beyond. This effort enhances US leadership in basic research, human capacity building, and technical development to meet energy, water, and food access needs worldwide with positive environmental and economic sustainability benefits.

The research theme of this program addresses grand challenges in the design, implementation and coordination of food, energy and water systems within spatial and temporal constraints. Trainees will research topics such as capturing and reusing nutrients and water in organic waste products, development of small-scale water and energy technologies necessary for the agricultural sector and developing infrastructures and lifecycle methodologies to collect integrated information and data on food, energy, and water systems. Integrating human-centered design, innovative business models, and technological advancements with an interdisciplinary framework of development and continual impact analysis, this program provides cross-cultural learning, prototyping and scaling, and new models for productive multi-stakeholder collaboration. The model for STEM graduate education is one that emphasizes immersive interdisciplinary training, featuring team-taught courses that pair faculty in a technology discipline with one in business/social sciences using hands-on project-based learning approaches. Specific training components include: (1) interdisciplinary research activities and field training, (2) formal coursework, (3) creation of a FEWS concentration as a PhD minor, (4) creation of a FEWS masters' level certificate, (5) career development, (6) online modules & tools, and (7) formative assessment and evaluation of the program's effectiveness. Trainees will master the interdisciplinary skills needed to create actionable and impactful research that is transferable from the lab to the field at scale. These skills will be highly transferable to contexts beyond poverty alleviation and will contribute to 21st century workforce development. 

The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) program is designed to encourage the development and implementation of bold, new potentially transformative models for STEM graduate education training. The Traineeship Track is dedicated to effective training of STEM graduate students in high priority interdisciplinary research areas, through the comprehensive traineeship model that is innovative, evidence-based, and aligned with changing workforce and research needs.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Innovations at the Nexus of Food-Energy-

por.por_cntn:
The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) program on  STEM Training for Actionable Research and Global Impact  successfully addressed the challenges at the intersection of food, energy and water systems (FEWS) as critical domains for a more equitable and sustainable future as defined by the UN's sustainable development goals . Over the project's 5-year duration and 2 years of no-cost extension, the interdisciplinary training program provided cutting-edge education and research opportunities for graduate students, fostering human-centered design innovation and preparing a new generation of researchers equipped to tackle complex FEWs challenges. The objective of the InFEWS training program is to train a new generation of interdisciplinary STEM researchers and practitioners to develop novel and lasting approaches and technologies for poverty alleviation and for positive global impact within the nexus of FEWS. The academic program implemented through this award addressed FEWS challenges through the following academic mechanisms:

  • interdisciplinary research activities,
  • formal coursework,
  • immersive lab and field training,
  • creating a FEWS concentration within the Ph.D. minor in Development Engineering
  • create new opportunities for InFEWS master’s level students,
  • career development,
  • online modules & tools, and
  • formative assessment and evaluation of the program’s effectiveness in developing 21st century skill sets critical for the multinational workforces of today.

Through the above mechanism the key outcomes of the program include:

●      The program funded 88 NRT Fellows across 18 departments on campus. Of these students, 40 Fellows from 10 different departments were funded for one year with tuition and stipend. The departments are: Civil and Environmental Engineering (13); Energy and Resource Group (10); Environmental Science, Policy and Management (5); Mechanical Engineering (3); College of Environmental Design (3); Agriculture Resource Economics and Business (2); School of Information (1); Social Welfare (1); Education (1); Public Health (1). In addition, the program had an educational impact on approximately 550 students who attended different parts of the program and events for students.

●      Altogether, trainees successfully conducted close to 100 original research projects of which at least 40 included collaboration with external organizations within the USA. Examples of interdisciplinary research with partners in the USA include: The Farm-Based Education Network in Vermont with the mission to promote farm-based education; The California Adaptation Forum, a forum of professional meeting to engaging in a wide array of activities that addressed California’s pressing climate adaptation issues and needs; and the CLEO Institute in Florida, dedicated to climate crisis education and advocacy. Other students implemented multidisciplinary research in collaboration with international organizations worldwide such as: the Center for Demographic, Urban and Environmental Studies (CEDUA) in Mexico; The Women’s Mobility and Collaborative Planning in Urban Malawi; and Rikolto in Indonesia, an international NGO with more than 40 years’ experience in partnering with farmer organizations and food chain stakeholders across Africa, Asia, Europe and Latin America.

●      Overall, 21% of graduating students continued to academic positions, 11.5% are working at a non-profit organization, 19.5% are working for for-profit companies and 8% for government organizations, 5.5% consulting, and the remaining 34.5% are current students.

●      Diversity and Inclusion: With an academic focus on multidisciplinary research that serves under-resourced communities around the world, the program achieved a diverse cohort of trainees, with 65% of the students identifying as women, compared to 32.8% at UC Berkeley’s School of Engineering (2023) and 34% identifying as underrepresented minorities compared to 16.4% URM at UC Berkeley’s School of Engineering (2023).

por.por_txt_cntn:
The NSF Research Traineeship (NRT) program on STEM Training for Actionable Research and Global Impact successfully addressed the challenges at the intersection of food, energy and water systems (FEWS) as critical domains for a more equitable and sustainable future as defined by the UN's sustainable development goals . Over the project's 5-year duration and 2 years of no-cost extension, the interdisciplinary training program provided cutting-edge education and research opportunities for graduate students, fostering human-centered design innovation and preparing a new generation of researchers equipped to tackle complex FEWs challenges. The objective of the InFEWS training program is to train a new generation of interdisciplinary STEM researchers and practitioners to develop novel and lasting approaches and technologies for poverty alleviation and for positive global impact within the nexus of FEWS. The academic program implemented through this award addressed FEWS challenges through the following academic mechanisms:

interdisciplinary research activities,
formal coursework,
immersive lab and field training,
creating a FEWS concentration within the Ph.D. minor in Development Engineering
create new opportunities for InFEWS masters level students,
career development,
online modules & tools, and
formative assessment and evaluation of the programs effectiveness in developing 21st century skill sets critical for the multinational workforces of today.



Through the above mechanism the key outcomes of the program include:


● The program funded 88 NRT Fellows across 18 departments on campus. Of these students, 40 Fellows from 10 different departments were funded for one year with tuition and stipend. The departments are: Civil and Environmental Engineering (13); Energy and Resource Group (10); Environmental Science, Policy and Management (5); Mechanical Engineering (3); College of Environmental Design (3); Agriculture Resource Economics and Business (2); School of Information (1); Social Welfare (1); Education (1); Public Health (1). In addition, the program had an educational impact on approximately 550 students who attended different parts of the program and events for students.


● Altogether, trainees successfully conducted close to 100 original research projects of which at least 40 included collaboration with external organizations within the USA. Examples of interdisciplinary research with partners in the USA include: The Farm-Based Education Network in Vermont with the mission to promote farm-based education; The California Adaptation Forum, a forum of professional meeting to engaging in a wide array of activities that addressed Californias pressing climate adaptation issues and needs; and the CLEO Institute in Florida, dedicated to climate crisis education and advocacy. Other students implemented multidisciplinary research in collaboration with international organizations worldwide such as: the Center for Demographic, Urban and Environmental Studies (CEDUA) in Mexico; The Womens Mobility and Collaborative Planning in Urban Malawi; and Rikolto in Indonesia, an international NGO with more than 40 years experience in partnering with farmer organizations and food chain stakeholders across Africa, Asia, Europe and Latin America.


● Overall, 21% of graduating students continued to academic positions, 11.5% are working at a non-profit organization, 19.5% are working for for-profit companies and 8% for government organizations, 5.5% consulting, and the remaining 34.5% are current students.


● Diversity and Inclusion: With an academic focus on multidisciplinary research that serves under-resourced communities around the world, the program achieved a diverse cohort of trainees, with 65% of the students identifying as women, compared to 32.8% at UC Berkeleys School of Engineering (2023) and 34% identifying as underrepresented minorities compared to 16.4% URM at UC Berkeleys School of Engineering (2023).
